page.title: 02HOWNAM'S RESIDENT POPULATION
page.content: In this part of the Scottish Borders, round the village of Hownam, there are only 22 houses.Two of these are empty, eight are used as second or holiday homes and are occupied for about seven months of the year, and the remaining 12 are the permanant residences of the population. This comprises 10 children and thirty one adults, catagorised as two students, twenty four working adults, and five pensioners.The houses are almost all stone, with the majority being two storied detached. There is one modern bungalow.There is no problem with employment in the area with only one adult unemployed,and all but four working within this block. Of the remainder all the men and some of the women work on the land, either as employer or employee, sometimes with little help except their own families. Such is the way of rural communities.
